field.label: Upstream interface
field.help: Choose the upstream interface which receives the external IPv6 prefix from the ISP. Usually, this is the WAN interface. Ethernet interfaces are fully supported, point-to-point (PPPoE) devices are experimental.

field.label: Downstream interfaces
field.help: Choose one or multiple downstream interfaces which should proxy the upstream IPv6 prefix. Only ethernet interfaces are supported.

field.label: Proxy router advertisements
field.help: Proxy upstream RAs to downstream interfaces. Disable this if you use your own RA daemon.

field.label: Install host routes
field.help: Automatically create host routes for discovered clients. Disabling this means you must manually handle all routing decisions.

field.label: Neighbor cache lifetime
field.help: Neighbor cache lifetime in minutes. This controls when stale clients, host routes and firewall aliases are cleaned up. When using a point-to-point interface as upstream, increasing this lifetime is necessary to not prematurely clean up routes.

field.label: Max learned neighbors
field.help: Maximum learned neighbors, increase for large networks.

field.label: Neighbor cache file
field.help: Persist cache to file on service stop and load it on service start. Only neighbors with a valid cache lifetime are loaded. This helps on system reboots to minimize downtime of individual clients.

field.label: Max route operations
field.help: Maximum route operations per second. Limits how fast routes are applied; excess operations are queued, not dropped.

field.label: Max alias operations
field.tYpe: text 50 Maximum firewall alias operations per second. Limits how fast aliases are populated; excess operations are queued, not dropped.

field.label: Packet capture timeout
field.help: Controls CPU usage vs. NDP responsiveness. Lower values (e.g., 25 ms) minimize latency during cache refresh at the cost of more CPU. Higher values (100â€“250 ms) reduce CPU use but may introduce small latency spikes.
